trans-unit.source: Import your publish settings file in Visual Studio 2013 | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Import your publish settings file in Visual Studio 2013 | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to import a subscription publish settings file for your Azure Mobile Services application in Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to import a subscription publish settings file for your Azure Mobile Services application in Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: Import your subscription publish settings file in Visual Studio 2013
trans-unit.target: Import your subscription publish settings file in Visual Studio 2013

trans-unit.source: Before you can create the mobile service, you must import the publish settings file from your Azure subscription into Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Before you can create the mobile service, you must import the publish settings file from your Azure subscription into Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: This enables Visual Studio to connect to Azure on your behalf.
trans-unit.target: This enables Visual Studio to connect to Azure on your behalf.

trans-unit.source: Beginning with Visual Studio 2013 Update 2, you no longer need to use a publish settings file.
trans-unit.target: Beginning with Visual Studio 2013 Update 2, you no longer need to use a publish settings file.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio is able to connect directly to Azure using the credentials that you provide.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio is able to connect directly to Azure using the credentials that you provide.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio 2013, open Solution Explorer, right-click the project then click Add and then Connected Service....
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio 2013, open Solution Explorer, right-click the project then click Add and then Connected Service....

trans-unit.source: <linkText>add connected service</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>add connected service</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Services Manager dialog, click Create service..., then select from Subscription in the Create Mobile Service dialog.
trans-unit.target: In the Services Manager dialog, click Create service..., then select from Subscription in the Create Mobile Service dialog.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>create a new mobile service from VS 2013</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>create a new mobile service from VS 2013</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In Import Azure Subscriptions, click Download subscription file, login to your Azure account (if required), click Save when your browser requests to save the file.
trans-unit.target: In Import Azure Subscriptions, click Download subscription file, login to your Azure account (if required), click Save when your browser requests to save the file.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>download subscription file in VS</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>download subscription file in VS</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The login window is displayed in the browser, which may be behind your Visual Studio window.
trans-unit.target: The login window is displayed in the browser, which may be behind your Visual Studio window.

trans-unit.source: Remember to make a note of where you saved the downloaded .publishsettings file.
trans-unit.target: Remember to make a note of where you saved the downloaded .publishsettings file.

trans-unit.source: You can skip this step if your project is already connected to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can skip this step if your project is already connected to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Click Browse, navigate to the location where you saved the .publishsettings file, select the file, then click Open and then Import.
trans-unit.target: Click Browse, navigate to the location where you saved the .publishsettings file, select the file, then click Open and then Import.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>import subscription in VS</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>import subscription in VS</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio imports the data needed to connect to your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio imports the data needed to connect to your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: When your subscription already has one or more existing mobile services, the service names are displayed.
trans-unit.target: When your subscription already has one or more existing mobile services, the service names are displayed.

trans-unit.source: After importing the publish settings, consider deleting the downloaded .publishsettings file as it contains information that can be used by others to access your account.
trans-unit.target: After importing the publish settings, consider deleting the downloaded .publishsettings file as it contains information that can be used by others to access your account.

trans-unit.source: Secure the file if you plan to keep it for use in other connected app projects.
trans-unit.target: Secure the file if you plan to keep it for use in other connected app projects.
